trans-unit.source: App Model v2.0 OAuth Protocol | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: App Model v2.0 OAuth Protocol | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Building web applications using Azure AD's implementation of the OAuth 2.0 authentication protocol.
trans-unit.target: Building web applications using Azure AD's implementation of the OAuth 2.0 authentication protocol.

trans-unit.source: App model v2.0 preview: Protocols - OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code Flow
trans-unit.target: App model v2.0 preview: Protocols - OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code Flow

trans-unit.source: The OAuth 2.0 authorization code grant can be used in apps that are installed on a device to gain access to protected resources, such as web APIs.
trans-unit.target: The OAuth 2.0 authorization code grant can be used in apps that are installed on a device to gain access to protected resources, such as web APIs.

trans-unit.source: Using the app model v2.0's implementation of OAuth 2.0, you can add sign in and API access to your mobile and desktop apps.
trans-unit.target: Using the app model v2.0's implementation of OAuth 2.0, you can add sign in and API access to your mobile and desktop apps.

trans-unit.source: This guide is language-independent, and describes how to send and receive HTTP messages without using any of our open-source libraries.
trans-unit.target: This guide is language-independent, and describes how to send and receive HTTP messages without using any of our open-source libraries.

trans-unit.source: This information applies to the v2.0 app model public preview.
trans-unit.target: This information applies to the v2.0 app model public preview.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the [Azure Active Directory Developer Guide](active-directory-developers-guide.md).
trans-unit.target: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the [Azure Active Directory Developer Guide](active-directory-developers-guide.md).

trans-unit.source: The OAuth 2.0 authorization code flow is described in in [section 4.1 of the OAuth 2.0 specification](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749).
trans-unit.target: The OAuth 2.0 authorization code flow is described in in [section 4.1 of the OAuth 2.0 specification](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749).

trans-unit.source: It is used to perform authentication and authorization in the majority of app types, including [web apps](active-directory-v2-flows.md#web-apps) and [natively installed apps](active-directory-v2-flows.md#mobile-and-native-apps).
trans-unit.target: It is used to perform authentication and authorization in the majority of app types, including [web apps](active-directory-v2-flows.md#web-apps) and [natively installed apps](active-directory-v2-flows.md#mobile-and-native-apps).

trans-unit.source: It enables apps to securely acquire access_tokens which can be used to access resources that are secured using the v2.0 app model.
trans-unit.target: It enables apps to securely acquire access_tokens which can be used to access resources that are secured using the v2.0 app model.

trans-unit.source: Request an Authorization Code
trans-unit.target: Request an Authorization Code

trans-unit.source: The authorization code flow begins with the client directing the user to the `/authorize` endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The authorization code flow begins with the client directing the user to the `/authorize` endpoint.

trans-unit.source: In this request, the client indicates the permissions it needs to acquire from the user:
trans-unit.target: In this request, the client indicates the permissions it needs to acquire from the user:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: client_id
trans-unit.target: client_id

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: The Application Id that the registration portal ([apps.dev.microsoft.com](https://apps.dev.microsoft.com)) assigned your app.
trans-unit.target: The Application Id that the registration portal ([apps.dev.microsoft.com](https://apps.dev.microsoft.com)) assigned your app.

trans-unit.source: response_type
trans-unit.target: response_type

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: Must include `code` for the authorization code flow.
trans-unit.target: Must include `code` for the authorization code flow.

trans-unit.source: redirect_uri
trans-unit.target: redirect_uri

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: The redirect_uri of your app, where authentication responses can be sent and receieved by your app.
trans-unit.target: The redirect_uri of your app, where authentication responses can be sent and receieved by your app.

trans-unit.source: It must exactly match one of the redirect_uris you registered in the portal, except it must be url encoded.
trans-unit.target: It must exactly match one of the redirect_uris you registered in the portal, except it must be url encoded.

trans-unit.source: scope
trans-unit.target: scope

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: A space-separated list of scopes.
trans-unit.target: A space-separated list of scopes.

trans-unit.source: A single scope value indicates to the v2.0 endpoint both the resource and the permissions to that resource being requested.
trans-unit.target: A single scope value indicates to the v2.0 endpoint both the resource and the permissions to that resource being requested.

trans-unit.source: Scopes take the form `<app identifier URI>/<scope value>`.
trans-unit.target: Scopes take the form `<app identifier URI>/<scope value>`.

trans-unit.source: In the example above, the app identifier for the Azure AD Graph API is used, `https://graph.windows.net`, and two permissions are requested: `directory.read` and `directory.write`.
trans-unit.target: In the example above, the app identifier for the Azure AD Graph API is used, `https://graph.windows.net`, and two permissions are requested: `directory.read` and `directory.write`.

trans-unit.source: For a more detailed explanation of scopes, refer to the [app model v2.0 scope reference](active-directory-v2-scopes.md).
trans-unit.target: For a more detailed explanation of scopes, refer to the [app model v2.0 scope reference](active-directory-v2-scopes.md).

trans-unit.source: response_mode
trans-unit.target: response_mode

trans-unit.source: recommended
trans-unit.target: recommended

trans-unit.source: Specifies the method that should be used to send the resulting authorization_code back to your app.
trans-unit.target: Specifies the method that should be used to send the resulting authorization_code back to your app.

trans-unit.source: Can be one of 'query', 'form_post', or 'fragment'.
trans-unit.target: Can be one of 'query', 'form_post', or 'fragment'.

trans-unit.source: state
trans-unit.target: state

trans-unit.source: recommended
trans-unit.target: recommended

trans-unit.source: A value included in the request that will also be returned in the token response.
trans-unit.target: A value included in the request that will also be returned in the token response.

trans-unit.source: It can be a string of any content that you wish.
trans-unit.target: It can be a string of any content that you wish.

trans-unit.source: A randomly generated unique value is typically used for preventing cross-site request forgery attacks.
trans-unit.target: A randomly generated unique value is typically used for preventing cross-site request forgery attacks.

trans-unit.source: The state is also used to encode information about the user's state in the app before the authentication request occurred, such as the page or view they were on.
trans-unit.target: The state is also used to encode information about the user's state in the app before the authentication request occurred, such as the page or view they were on.

trans-unit.source: prompt
trans-unit.target: prompt

trans-unit.source: optional
trans-unit.target: optional

trans-unit.source: Indicates the type of user interaction that is required.
trans-unit.target: Indicates the type of user interaction that is required.

trans-unit.source: The only valid values at this time are 'login', 'none', and 'consent'.
trans-unit.target: The only valid values at this time are 'login', 'none', and 'consent'.

trans-unit.source: `prompt=login` will force the user to enter their credentials on that request, negating single-sign on.
trans-unit.target: `prompt=login` will force the user to enter their credentials on that request, negating single-sign on.

trans-unit.source: `prompt=none` is the opposite - it will ensure that the user is not presented with any interactive prompt whatsoever.
trans-unit.target: `prompt=none` is the opposite - it will ensure that the user is not presented with any interactive prompt whatsoever.

trans-unit.source: If the request cannot be completed silently via single-sign on, the v2.0 endpoint will return an error.
trans-unit.target: If the request cannot be completed silently via single-sign on, the v2.0 endpoint will return an error.

trans-unit.source: `prompt=consent` will trigger the OAuth consent dialog after the user signs in, asking the user to grant permissions to the app.
trans-unit.target: `prompt=consent` will trigger the OAuth consent dialog after the user signs in, asking the user to grant permissions to the app.

trans-unit.source: login_hint
trans-unit.target: login_hint

trans-unit.source: optional
trans-unit.target: optional

trans-unit.source: Can be used to pre-fill the username/email address field of the sign in page for the user.
trans-unit.target: Can be used to pre-fill the username/email address field of the sign in page for the user.

trans-unit.source: At this point, the user will be asked to enter their credentials and complete the authentication.
trans-unit.target: At this point, the user will be asked to enter their credentials and complete the authentication.

trans-unit.source: The v2.0 endpoint will also ensure that the user has consented to the permissions indicated in the `scope` query parameter.
trans-unit.target: The v2.0 endpoint will also ensure that the user has consented to the permissions indicated in the `scope` query parameter.

trans-unit.source: If the user has not consented to any of those permissions, it will ask the user to consent to the required permissions.
trans-unit.target: If the user has not consented to any of those permissions, it will ask the user to consent to the required permissions.

trans-unit.source: Details of [permissions, consent, and multi-tenant apps are provided here](active-directory-v2-scopes.md).
trans-unit.target: Details of [permissions, consent, and multi-tenant apps are provided here](active-directory-v2-scopes.md).

trans-unit.source: Once the user authenticates and grants consent, the v2.0 endpoint will return a response to your app at the indicated `redirect_uri`, using the method specified in the `response_mode` parameter.
trans-unit.target: Once the user authenticates and grants consent, the v2.0 endpoint will return a response to your app at the indicated `redirect_uri`, using the method specified in the `response_mode` parameter.

trans-unit.source: A successful response using `response_mode=query` looks like:
trans-unit.target: A successful response using `response_mode=query` looks like:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: code
trans-unit.target: code

trans-unit.source: The authorization_code that the app requested.
trans-unit.target: The authorization_code that the app requested.

trans-unit.source: The app can use the authorization code to request an access token for the target resource.
trans-unit.target: The app can use the authorization code to request an access token for the target resource.

trans-unit.source: Authorization_codes are very short lived, typically they expire after about 10 minutes.
trans-unit.target: Authorization_codes are very short lived, typically they expire after about 10 minutes.

trans-unit.source: session_state
trans-unit.target: session_state

trans-unit.source: A unique value that identifies the current user session.
trans-unit.target: A unique value that identifies the current user session.

trans-unit.source: This value is a GUID, but should be treated as an opaque value that is passed without examination.
trans-unit.target: This value is a GUID, but should be treated as an opaque value that is passed without examination.

trans-unit.source: state
trans-unit.target: state

trans-unit.source: If a state parameter is included in the request, the same value should appear in the response.
trans-unit.target: If a state parameter is included in the request, the same value should appear in the response.

trans-unit.source: The app should verify that the state values in the request and response are identical.
trans-unit.target: The app should verify that the state values in the request and response are identical.

trans-unit.source: Error responses may also be sent to the `redirect_uri` so the app can handle them appropriately:
trans-unit.target: Error responses may also be sent to the `redirect_uri` so the app can handle them appropriately:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: error
trans-unit.target: error

trans-unit.source: An error code string that can be used to classify types of errors that occur, and can be used to react to errors.
trans-unit.target: An error code string that can be used to classify types of errors that occur, and can be used to react to errors.

trans-unit.source: error_description
trans-unit.target: error_description

trans-unit.source: A specific error message that can help a developer identify the root cause of an authentication error.
trans-unit.target: A specific error message that can help a developer identify the root cause of an authentication error.

trans-unit.source: Request an Access Token
trans-unit.target: Request an Access Token

trans-unit.source: Now that you've acquired an authorization_code and have been granted permission by the user, you can redeem the `code` for an `access_token` to the desired resource, by sending a `POST` request to the `/token` endpoint:
trans-unit.target: Now that you've acquired an authorization_code and have been granted permission by the user, you can redeem the `code` for an `access_token` to the desired resource, by sending a `POST` request to the `/token` endpoint:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: client_id
trans-unit.target: client_id

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: The Application Id that the registration portal ([apps.dev.microsoft.com](https://apps.dev.microsoft.com)) assigned your app.
trans-unit.target: The Application Id that the registration portal ([apps.dev.microsoft.com](https://apps.dev.microsoft.com)) assigned your app.

trans-unit.source: grant_type
trans-unit.target: grant_type

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: Must be `authorization_code` for the authorization code flow.
trans-unit.target: Must be `authorization_code` for the authorization code flow.

trans-unit.source: scope
trans-unit.target: scope

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: A space-separated list of scopes.
trans-unit.target: A space-separated list of scopes.

trans-unit.source: The scopes requested in this leg must be equivalent to or a subset of the scopes requested in the first leg.
trans-unit.target: The scopes requested in this leg must be equivalent to or a subset of the scopes requested in the first leg.

trans-unit.source: If the scopes specified in this request span multiple resource servers, then the v2.0 endpoint will return a token for the resource specified in the first scope.
trans-unit.target: If the scopes specified in this request span multiple resource servers, then the v2.0 endpoint will return a token for the resource specified in the first scope.

trans-unit.source: For a more detailed explanation of scopes, refer to [permissions, consent, and scopes](active-directory-v2-scopes.md).
trans-unit.target: For a more detailed explanation of scopes, refer to [permissions, consent, and scopes](active-directory-v2-scopes.md).

trans-unit.source: code
trans-unit.target: code

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: The authorization_code that you acquired in the first leg of the flow.
trans-unit.target: The authorization_code that you acquired in the first leg of the flow.

trans-unit.source: client_secret
trans-unit.target: client_secret

trans-unit.source: required for web apps
trans-unit.target: required for web apps

trans-unit.source: The application secret that you created in the app registration portal for your app.
trans-unit.target: The application secret that you created in the app registration portal for your app.

trans-unit.source: It should not be used in a native app, because client_secrets cannot be reliably stored on devices.
trans-unit.target: It should not be used in a native app, because client_secrets cannot be reliably stored on devices.

trans-unit.source: It is required for web apps and web APIs, which have the ability to store the client_secret securely on the server side.
trans-unit.target: It is required for web apps and web APIs, which have the ability to store the client_secret securely on the server side.

trans-unit.source: A successful token response will look like:
trans-unit.target: A successful token response will look like:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: access_token
trans-unit.target: access_token

trans-unit.source: The requested access token.
trans-unit.target: The requested access token.

trans-unit.source: The app can use this token to authenticate to the secured resource, such as a web API.
trans-unit.target: The app can use this token to authenticate to the secured resource, such as a web API.

trans-unit.source: token_type
trans-unit.target: token_type

trans-unit.source: Indicates the token type value.
trans-unit.target: Indicates the token type value.

trans-unit.source: The only type that Azure AD supports is Bearer
trans-unit.target: The only type that Azure AD supports is Bearer

trans-unit.source: expires_in
trans-unit.target: expires_in

trans-unit.source: How long the access token is valid (in seconds).
trans-unit.target: How long the access token is valid (in seconds).

trans-unit.source: scope
trans-unit.target: scope

trans-unit.source: The scopes that the access_token is valid for.
trans-unit.target: The scopes that the access_token is valid for.

trans-unit.source: refresh_token
trans-unit.target: refresh_token

trans-unit.source: An OAuth 2.0 refresh token.
trans-unit.target: An OAuth 2.0 refresh token.

trans-unit.source: The app can use this token acquire additional access tokens after the current access token expires.
trans-unit.target: The app can use this token acquire additional access tokens after the current access token expires.

trans-unit.source: Refresh_tokens are long-lived, and can be used to retain access to resources for extended periods of time.
trans-unit.target: Refresh_tokens are long-lived, and can be used to retain access to resources for extended periods of time.

trans-unit.source: For more detail, refer to the [v2.0 token reference](active-directory-v2-tokens.md).
trans-unit.target: For more detail, refer to the [v2.0 token reference](active-directory-v2-tokens.md).

trans-unit.source: id_token
trans-unit.target: id_token

trans-unit.source: An unsigned JSON Web Token (JWT).
trans-unit.target: An unsigned JSON Web Token (JWT).

trans-unit.source: The app can base64Url decode the segments of this token to request information about the user who signed in.
trans-unit.target: The app can base64Url decode the segments of this token to request information about the user who signed in.

trans-unit.source: The app can cache the values and display them, but it should not rely on them for any authorization or security boundaries.
trans-unit.target: The app can cache the values and display them, but it should not rely on them for any authorization or security boundaries.

trans-unit.source: For more information about id_tokens see the [v2.0 app model token reference](active-directory-v2-tokens.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about id_tokens see the [v2.0 app model token reference](active-directory-v2-tokens.md).

trans-unit.source: id_token_expires_in
trans-unit.target: id_token_expires_in

trans-unit.source: How long the id token is valid (in seconds).
trans-unit.target: How long the id token is valid (in seconds).

trans-unit.source: Error responses will look like:
trans-unit.target: Error responses will look like:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: error
trans-unit.target: error

trans-unit.source: An error code string that can be used to classify types of errors that occur, and can be used to react to errors.
trans-unit.target: An error code string that can be used to classify types of errors that occur, and can be used to react to errors.

trans-unit.source: error_description
trans-unit.target: error_description

trans-unit.source: A specific error message that can help a developer identify the root cause of an authentication error.
trans-unit.target: A specific error message that can help a developer identify the root cause of an authentication error.

trans-unit.source: Use the Access Token
trans-unit.target: Use the Access Token

trans-unit.source: Now that you've successfully acquired an `access_token`, you can use the token in requests to Web APIs by including it in the `Authorization` header:
trans-unit.target: Now that you've successfully acquired an `access_token`, you can use the token in requests to Web APIs by including it in the `Authorization` header:

trans-unit.source: Refresh the Access Token
trans-unit.target: Refresh the Access Token

trans-unit.source: Access_tokens are short lived, and you must refresh them after they expire to continue accessing resources.
trans-unit.target: Access_tokens are short lived, and you must refresh them after they expire to continue accessing resources.

trans-unit.source: You can do so by submitting another `POST` request to the `/token` endpoint, this time providing the `refresh_token` instead of the `code`:
trans-unit.target: You can do so by submitting another `POST` request to the `/token` endpoint, this time providing the `refresh_token` instead of the `code`:

trans-unit.source: Parameter
trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: client_id
trans-unit.target: client_id

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: The Application Id that the registration portal ([apps.dev.microsoft.com](https://apps.dev.microsoft.com)) assigned your app.
trans-unit.target: The Application Id that the registration portal ([apps.dev.microsoft.com](https://apps.dev.microsoft.com)) assigned your app.

trans-unit.source: grant_type
trans-unit.target: grant_type

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: Must be `refresh_token` for this leg of the authorization code flow.
trans-unit.target: Must be `refresh_token` for this leg of the authorization code flow.

trans-unit.source: scope
trans-unit.target: scope

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: A space-separated list of scopes.
trans-unit.target: A space-separated list of scopes.

trans-unit.source: The scopes requested in this leg must be equivalent to or a subset of the scopes requested in the original authorization_code request leg.
trans-unit.target: The scopes requested in this leg must be equivalent to or a subset of the scopes requested in the original authorization_code request leg.

trans-unit.source: If the scopes specified in this request span multiple resource servers, then the v2.0 endpoint will return a token for the resource specified in the first scope.
trans-unit.target: If the scopes specified in this request span multiple resource servers, then the v2.0 endpoint will return a token for the resource specified in the first scope.

trans-unit.source: For a more detailed explanation of scopes, refer to [permissions, consent, and scopes](active-directory-v2-scopes.md).
trans-unit.target: For a more detailed explanation of scopes, refer to [permissions, consent, and scopes](active-directory-v2-scopes.md).

trans-unit.source: refresh_token
trans-unit.target: refresh_token

trans-unit.source: required
trans-unit.target: required

trans-unit.source: The refresh_token that you acquired in the second leg of the flow.
trans-unit.target: The refresh_token that you acquired in the second leg of the flow.

trans-unit.source: client_secret
trans-unit.target: client_secret

trans-unit.source: required for web apps
trans-unit.target: required for web apps

trans-unit.source: The application secret that you created in the app registration portal for your app.
trans-unit.target: The application secret that you created in the app registration portal for your app.

trans-unit.source: It should not be used in a native app, because client_secrets cannot be reliably stored on devices.
trans-unit.target: It should not be used in a native app, because client_secrets cannot be reliably stored on devices.

trans-unit.source: It is required for web apps and web APIs, which have the ability to store the client_secret securely on the server side.
trans-unit.target: It is required for web apps and web APIs, which have the ability to store the client_secret securely on the server side.

trans-unit.target: A successful token response will look like:

trans-unit.target: Parameter

trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: access_token
trans-unit.target: access_token

trans-unit.source: The requested access token.
trans-unit.target: The requested access token.

trans-unit.source: The app can use this token to authenticate to the secured resource, such as a web API.
trans-unit.target: The app can use this token to authenticate to the secured resource, such as a web API.

trans-unit.target: token_type

trans-unit.source: Indicates the token type value.
trans-unit.target: Indicates the token type value.

trans-unit.source: The only type that Azure AD supports is Bearer
trans-unit.target: The only type that Azure AD supports is Bearer

trans-unit.target: expires_in

trans-unit.source: refresh_token
trans-unit.target: refresh_token

trans-unit.source: A new OAuth 2.0 refresh token.
trans-unit.target: A new OAuth 2.0 refresh token.

trans-unit.source: You should replace the old refresh token with this newly acquired refresh token to ensure your refresh tokens remain valid for as long as possible.
trans-unit.target: You should replace the old refresh token with this newly acquired refresh token to ensure your refresh tokens remain valid for as long as possible.

trans-unit.source: The app can cache the values and display them, but it should not rely on them for any authorization or security boundaries.

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: At a high level, the entire authentication flow for a native/mobile application looks a bit like this:
trans-unit.target: At a high level, the entire authentication flow for a native/mobile application looks a bit like this:

trans-unit.source: OAuth Auth Code Flow
trans-unit.target: OAuth Auth Code Flow
